review_title: Great benefits, positive culture and values, and decent pay.
job_title: Medical Social Worker in Memphis, TN
pros:
-The environment is open and welcoming. Employees across all disciplines seem to enjoy their jobs.
-Parking in the garage is extremely convenient.
-The Willows Cafe (cafeteria) has low costing food, and the food tastes good.
-Management is effective, and there are opportunities for for upward mobility.
-The benefits package is almost impossible to find in another healthcare or non-healthcare setting. It includes tuition reimbursement, the BEST healthcare plan at a low biweekly premium, and discounts with local businesses.
cons:
-In my opinion, the pay rate could be higher, but it is satisfactory (especially considering the pros of this company/location).
-Social Workers are expected to be on call for the ED overnight (Monday-Friday) during 4 weeks in the year. This aspect is particularly stressful.
-For social workers, there is no funded or offered supervision for clinical hours. Thus, if one of your goals is to obtain clinical licensure (LCSW), you will unfortunately have to locate and pay a clinical supervisor elsewhere to reach this goal.

review_title: Cutbacks on benefits and staffing, and throwing money away on unnecessary tech - makes perfect sense
pros: I have been a Baptist employee for 5 years. The first several years of my Baptist experience was great. I received a good orientation, continuing education, plenty of support from my manager, and had everything I needed to do my job. Current pro's are: I still have a job and I still get my paycheck on time.
cons: The organization has taken a bad turn in the past 6 months. Despite making plenty of profit (remember, this is a non-profit organization), there has been a dramatic decrease in staffing, and the company is cutting benefits left and right -- no more tuition reimbursement for new hires, no more specialty certification reimbursement, no more preceptor pay, and the list goes on and on. Meanwhile, Baptist is spending millions of dollars on new equipment -- cardiac monitors are being replaced in areas where they work perfectly fine now, new iPhones are being issued to nursing staff to replace an already-working companion phone system. If Baptist doesn't have the money to pay the staff, where are these millions coming from for unnecessary technology.

So, what do you think is happening to it? You are very overworked. People are quitting because of the low pay and the work load. For example, there is not enough staff for the demand of new patients, and yet the hospital (Baptist-Desoto) is building  on to the ER to hold even more patients.  Another issue is a program called KATA. There is a constant creation of  new "KATA procedures" that should be stopped. Actual direct patient care staff input is NOT apart of the creative process.  The managers/higher ups DO listen to the actual floor staff. They know the problem, and yet nothing is done to fix them. There is always a new "innovative" step being added to the direct patient care staff members workloads. Almost ALL of these steps are pseudo-fixes. Last but not least, the constant harassment to come to work on your off days.

pros: There are no pros to working for this company. There claim to fame is Preaching, Teaching, and Healing and it's totally contradictory to the culture.

The silo mentality is believed to impact operations, reduce employee morale and may contribute to the overall failure of a company or its products and culture. There is no adherence to policy, senior leadership is totally unaware of just how bad management really is. Decisions are made based on feelings. Don't believe the tuition benefit, it's based upon who you are -just see what happens when you inquire. This company hides behind the infamous phrase "case by case basis" meaning how we feel about you.  There are no growth opportunities.  Communications sucks.
